Meta.ShortDescription: A type of facial paralysis that results in an inability to control the facial muscles on the affected side.

Symptoms.Symptom: One-sided facial droops that comes on within 72 hours
Both sides, resulting in total facial paralysis
Difficulty blinking, closing the eyes, smiling, frowning, salivation, raising eyebrows.
Loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3 of the tongue on the affected side.

Causes.Cause: Some viruses are thought to establish a persistent or latent infection without symptoms, in particular the varicella-zoster and epstein-barr viruses, both of the herpes family.
New viral activation could be preceded by trauma, environmental factors, and metabolic or emotional disorders.
Genetics has been found in 4-14% of cases.
3x more likely in pregnant women than non-pregnant

Diagnostics.Diagnostic: Diagnosis of exclusion, as no specific cause can be determined.
